Time for school! And it’s no surprise that
many of us are determined to study smarter

4.text:
instead of longer. But which study tips and
tricks actually work scientifically and can

10.text: help you get those perfect grades?

12.text:
First up, research shows that study sessions
are most effective in small, short chunks.

17.text:
Instead of cramming in a 10 hour study session,
it’s much more effective to spread it out

22.text:
into twenty 30 minute sessions over a few
weeks. This is because your brain is better

26.text:
at encoding information into the synapses
in short, repeated sessions as opposed to

31.text:
one large one. And this is why even learning
different skills - whether it’s swimming,

35.text:
tennis or a singing lesson - often follows
this same format!

39.text:
And while cramming and pulling all-nighters
may be a ritual, it turns out this is linked

44.text:
to the lowest grades. After prolonged nocturnal
study sessions, reasoning and memory may be

48.text:
negatively affected for up to four whole days.
Instead, setting up specific times in a day,

54.text:
or during the week just to study, primes your
brain by creating a routine, and over time

59.text:
studying actually becomes easier, as your
brain is trained to learn in those moments.

63.text:
And while many of us spend hours passively
re-reading our notes or highlighting a textbook,

68.text:
studies have shown this to be ineffective.
It doesn’t improve your understanding of

72.text:
topics nor does it link key concepts together.
It can even be detrimental as it draws your

77.text:
attention to less important information. Flash
cards, on the other hand, are proven to be

82.text:
excellent memory reinforcement tools. Whether
during your scheduled study times, or during

86.text: off times, like a bus ride home.

88.text:
It also helps to have a specific goal for
each study session. Instead of aimlessly studying,

93.text:
pick one aspect you will focus on - whether
it’s balancing chemical equations, or learning

97.text:
how to conjugate French verbs. If you can’t
explain it simply, then you don’t understand

102.text:
it well enough. In studies where individuals
were asked to learn a passage, and then half

106.text:
were told they would be tested on the material,
while the other half were told they would

109.text:
have to teach it to other students, participants
expecting to teach it did much better at understanding

114.text:
the main points. When you’re expecting to
teach, your brain organizes the information

119.text: in a more logical, coherent structure.

121.text:
Of course, practice, practice, practice! Not
only do practice tests put your brain in the

126.text:
environment, but even if you make mistakes,
they help identify gaps in your knowledge.

130.text:
Practice tests have also been shown to increase
confidence, thereby leading to better performance.

135.text:
So, where should you be studying? Research
shows that having a designated, sacred spot

140.text:
for study, that is well-equipped with every
tool you might need is best. Just like setting

144.text: times, this primes your brain for studying.

147.text:
Have an awesome study playlist? Not so fast...while
some studies have shown that certain types

152.text:
of classical music can help improve concentration,
a recent study has shown that learning with

157.text:
rhythmic background noise can be detrimental
to focus, and those not using music fared

162.text:
And if you haven’t already, PUT AWAY YOUR
PHONE! This is a no-brainer, but your texts

167.text:
and social media notifications severely decrease
concentration.
